Forwarded from PZDC While the Russian Federation Council of Ministers is coordinating the appointment of a new Minister of Emergency Situations proposed by Putin, the Russian president himself, at a meeting on transportation, sadly notes the unhappy prospects of the tourist season in Crimea. Since there are no planes flying here (you know why), you can only get to the Crimea by trains and cars. At the same time the railway capacity is already not enough, potential tourists have to give up bookings - they are already half as many as required.

In the meantime, the Crimean authorities are not telegraphing and not very worried, because they will still get money from the federal government, but they got used to do something themselves after eight years, and they don't know why, if Moscow gives them a new tranche and doesn't ask anything. And this means that they can tear down the architectural antiquities of the beginning of the last century, just to please the new landowners, who want to claim a billion dollars for the land.

In the meantime, Putin admits that nothing works in the Crimea "in an accurate, stable, smooth, and efficient manner" and that the local bureaucrats should be kicked out. The Crimean company Grand Service. Express has a shortage of passenger cars: they need four times as many. Tickets from Moscow to Sochi cost from 2.5-5 thousand.

Forwarded from Voenkor Kotenok Z Russian troops are advancing in the city limits of Krasny Liman, suppressing pockets of resistance by the enemy, whose actions reflect a sense of doom. The Russian Armed Forces have ruled out any possibility of bringing in reserves, while the city's defense loses all sense in the face of advancing units of the Russian Armed Forces.

In the second half of May 24, scattered groups of the enemy attempted to respond in the area of the hangars, but this fire is ineffective, the AFU fire points are effectively suppressed.

POWs note that the commanders of certain AFU units near Liman were tasked with breaking through in the direction of Sloviansk, where they could join up with the ostensible forces of the AFU grouping.

Morale in the Ukrainian units is depressed. The rank and file and junior commanders see no prospect of continuing to resist when the strongholds are cut off from the main defense forces, deprived of communication and combat control.

I'm not sure that even Switzerland will resist. In fact, its joining the sanctions against Russia was already a departure from 200 years of neutrality.

Sweden, by the way, also stayed out of European conflicts after the Napoleonic Wars, happily avoiding being dragged into two World Wars and the Cold War.

Even during World War II, there were more neutral states in Europe than now. Through the same Sweden there was trade in goods from the warring countries. There was no such freezing of trade ties as there is today with Russia.

What is happening now has not been seen in Europe for more than 200 years. And there are suspicions that Moldova's neutrality will also be brought to naught.
